description: Middle English rowein, from Anglo-Norman rewain, from an Old Northern French variant of Old French regain (“an increase”).

entries.meaning: A second crop of hay; aftermath.
A stubble field left unploughed until late in the autumn, so that it can be cropped by cattle.
examples: For the wintering of cattle, about September you must turn them out that you design to keep up for a winter or a spring market, and your cows, that give milk into your rowens, till snow or a hard frost comes, and they will need no fodder.
